meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny -

Ah, Rogue Legacy 2 - where do I even start? Like many others, I'm obsessed with this game. Okay, fine, maybe not "many others" since my friends and family think I've lost all sense of reality due to the constant stream of "just one more run" notifications on my phone.

Seriously though, this game is a masterclass in game design. Cellar Door Games has outdone themselves (or should I say, their ancestors?) with an addictive roguelike experience that's as beautiful as it is challenging.

Let's talk about the praise-worthy aspects. The world of Rogue Legacy 2 is stunning - vibrant, colorful, and full of wonder. Each biome feels like a new discovery, whether it's the eerie darkness of the caves or the sun-drenched beauty of the forest. And then there are the classes! Oh boy, do I love experimenting with different heir choices to see how they shape the gameplay experience.

But what truly sets Rogue Legacy 2 apart is its ability to balance challenge and replayability. Sure, it's not for everyone (I mean, I've died... a lot), but when you finally reach that "aha!" moment where everything clicks into place, it's pure bliss. And don't even get me started on the House Rules - having control over difficulty is like being the game master of your own destiny.

Of course, not everyone shares my enthusiasm (I mean, Edge Magazine, what's with the 70? Did you miss the memo about this game being a masterpiece?). Some critics have noted that the game can be overwhelming, but I think that's just part of its charm. The sheer scope of possibilities and pathways to explore is intoxicating.

All in all, Rogue Legacy 2 is a must-play for anyone who loves roguelikes or Metroidvanias (or both!). It's a testament to the power of game design when even us critics can't get enough. So go ahead, give it a try - but don't say I didn't warn you about the "just one more run" syndrome...
